Authors: Li, X., Wang, Y., Chen, Z.
Title: Electric vehicle adoption in smart cities: A systematic review
Source title: Transportation Research Part D: Transport and Environment
Abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive systematic review of electric vehicle (EV) adoption in smart cities. We analyze 150 peer-reviewed articles published between 2015-2024 to identify key factors influencing EV adoption, including infrastructure development, government policies, consumer attitudes, and technological advancements.
Author Keywords: Electric vehicles; Smart cities; Sustainable transportation; Adoption barriers; Policy
Index Keywords: Battery electric vehicles; Consumer acceptance; Charging infrastructure; Environmental impact; Purchase intention
References: Abbasi M., 2019, Transp. Res. Part D, 67, 123; Brown J., 2020, Energy Policy, 138, 111245; Chen S., 2021, J. Clean. Prod., 280, 124567; Davis F.D., 1989, MIS Quart., 13, 319
Correspondence Address: Li, X.; Tsinghua University, Department of Civil Engineering, Beijing, 100084, China; email: li.x@tsinghua.edu.cn
Abbreviated Source Title: Transp. Res. Part D Transp. Environ.

Authors: Zhang, L., Kumar, A., Patel, S.
Title: Autonomous vehicles and urban planning: Challenges and opportunities
Abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) will fundamentally transform urban planning and city design. This study examines the potential impacts of AV adoption on urban form, land use patterns, and transportation infrastructure. Through scenario analysis and expert interviews with 50 urban planners across 10 cities, we identify key planning challenges.
Author Keywords: Autonomous vehicles; Urban planning; Land use; Parking; Traffic management
Index Keywords: Self-driving cars; Automated vehicles; City design; Mobility as service; Shared mobility
References: Bansal P., 2017, Transport Res. A Pol., 106, 283; Fagnant DJ., 2015, Transport Res. A Pol., 77, 167; Milakis D., 2017, Urban Sci., 1, 32
Correspondence Address: Zhang, L.; UC Berkeley, Department of City and Regional Planning, Berkeley, CA, 94720, United States; email: zhang.lei@berkeley.edu

Title: Public transport optimization using big data analytics: A case study
Abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to public transport optimization using big data analytics from smart card transactions. We analyze 10 million trip records from Bangkok's BTS Skytrain system to identify passenger flow patterns, peak hour demand, and route optimization opportunities.
Author Keywords: Public transport; Big data; Route optimization; Passenger flow; Smart cards
Index Keywords: Bus rapid transit; Travel demand; Passenger counting; Origin-destination; Data mining
References: Cats O., 2015, Transport Res. C Emer., 52, 133; Gu Y., 2022, Transport Res. Rec., 2676, 234; Ma X., 2017, IEEE T. Intell. Transp., 18, 891
Correspondence Address: Hassan, M.; Chulalongkorn University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Civil Engineering, Bangkok, 10330, Thailand; email: 6870376421@student.chula.ac.th

Authors: Garcia, M., Silva, P., Santos, J.
Title: Bicycle sharing systems and urban sustainability: A meta-analysis
Abstract: This meta-analysis synthesizes findings from 75 studies on bicycle sharing systems (BSS) across global cities. We examine the relationship between BSS implementation and urban sustainability indicators including carbon emissions, physical activity levels, and social equity.
Author Keywords: Bicycle sharing; Urban sustainability; Carbon emissions; Active mobility; Social equity
Index Keywords: Bike-sharing programs; Sustainable transport; Environmental benefits; Public health; Urban mobility
References: DeMaio P., 2009, J. Public Transp., 12, 41; Fishman E., 2013, J. Transp. Health, 1, 66; Shaheen S., 2010, Transp. Res. Rec., 2143, 83
Correspondence Address: Garcia, M.; University of Barcelona, Department of Geography, Barcelona, 08007, Spain; email: m.garcia@ub.edu

Authors: Tanaka, H., Kim, J., Lee, S.
Title: Machine learning applications in traffic flow prediction: A systematic review
Source title: Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies
Abstract: This systematic review examines machine learning applications for traffic flow prediction from 2018-2023. We analyze 120 studies implementing various ML models including deep learning, random forests, and support vector machines. Performance metrics and practical implementation challenges are discussed.
Author Keywords: Machine learning; Traffic prediction; Deep learning; Neural networks; Intelligent transportation
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Traffic forecasting; Convolutional neural networks; Long short-term memory; Real-time prediction
References: Lv Y., 2015, IEEE T. Intell. Transp., 16, 865; Vlahogianni EI., 2014, Transport Res. C Emer., 43, 3; Zhang J., 2021, IEEE T. Knowl. Data En., 33, 23
Correspondence Address: Tanaka, H.; University of Tokyo, Department of Civil Engineering, Tokyo, 113-8656, Japan; email: tanaka@civil.t.u-tokyo.ac.jp
Abbreviated Source Title: Transp. Res. Part C Emerg. Technol.

Authors: Martinez, A., Brown, K., Wilson, T.
Title: Climate change impacts on transportation infrastructure: A global assessment
Abstract: This study assesses climate change impacts on transportation infrastructure globally. Using spatial analysis and climate models, we evaluate vulnerability of roads, bridges, and transit systems to extreme weather events, sea-level rise, and temperature changes across 50 countries.
Author Keywords: Climate change; Transportation infrastructure; Resilience; Adaptation; Vulnerability assessment
Index Keywords: Infrastructure damage; Extreme weather; Sea-level rise; Climate adaptation; Risk assessment
References: Koetse MJ., 2009, Transport Res. A Pol., 43, 251; Pregnolato M., 2017, Environ. Sci. Policy, 71, 97; IPCC, 2021, Climate Change Report
Correspondence Address: Martinez, A.; World Bank, Transport Global Practice, Washington, DC, 20433, United States; email: amartinez@worldbank.org
